review.title: What is Learning? A primary discussion about information and Representation
review.abstract: Nowadays, represented by Deep Learning techniques, the field of machine learning is experiencing unprecedented prosperity and its influence is demonstrated in academia, industry and civil society. "Intelligent" has become a label which could not be neglected for most applications; celebrities and scientists also warned that the development of full artificial intelligence may spell the end of the human race. It seems that the answer to building a computer system that could automatically improve with experience is right on the next corner. While for AI and machine learning researchers, it is a consensus that we are not anywhere near the core technique which could bring the Terminator, Number 5 or R2D2 into real life, and there is not even a formal definition about what is intelligence, or one of its basic properties: Learning. Therefore, even though researchers know these concerns are not necessary currently, there is no generalized explanation about why these concerns are not necessary, and what properties people should take into account that would make these concerns to be necessary. In this paper, starts from analysing the relation between information and its representation, a necessary condition for a model to be a learning model is proposed. This condition and related future works could be used to verify whether a system is able to learn or not, and enrich our understanding of learning: one important property of Intelligence.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Although researchers in the field of machine learning or artificial intelligence know that we are nowhere near the technology that could enable us to build a machine with real intelligence, almost all discussions about the various attributes of intelligence remain at a philosophical level, such as the ability to learn, the ability to think logically, self-confidence, or even emotions. Formal mathematical definitions of these attributes are very undefined, and we do not even have binary criteria to verify whether a system really has any of these attributes, let alone formal methods that can be used to analyze the level of each of these attributes. By generalizing our intuitive understanding of learning ability, this essay provides a concise necessary prerequisite to be a learning model. And this essay also presents other research guidelines that would allow us to analyze whether a model will be a learning model or a non-learning model during the development process. The discussion begins with intuitive introductions, the discussion of standpoint based on the following understanding of the conceptual process.

sections.heading: 1.1 Intuitive introduction: Information
sections.text: We are constantly surrounded by different information and we process it. And certainty plays a decisive role in the representation of information, because an information must be carried by at least one particular representation. • "I am 188cm": In this example, a certain number together with a unit (cm) represents information about height, the pronoun of the first person represents an identity related to height information. • "Left? Right!": In this example, the uncertainty of the context implies ambiguity. Even if we measure the uncertainty of a system (entropy), we get a certain number or a range with a certain limit; or if we cannot get a certain limit, we still have the certain representation of the system we are measuring; or even if we do not know which system we are measuring, we still have a certain definition of entropy; and if we have no certainty about anything, then there is no information at all. In other words, the amount of certainties, which also corresponds to the amount of information.

sections.heading: 1.2 Intuitive introduction: Learning
sections.text: We as human beings cannot perceive an enormous amount of physical realities in a natural way, such as the existence of almost all submicroscopic particles, the existence of a majority region of electromagnetic waves, the motion of the Earth, the fact that the Earth is a sphere, in fact, this list could continue to grow and encompasses almost all the knowledge we have learned since the birth of modern science, and we are all very familiar with the process of learning new knowledge based on known knowledge, and on new learned knowledge to learn even newer knowledge. First, this essay will give a general definition of the relative relationship between known knowledge and the new knowledge learned. Introduction of this definition begins with an example: a man has been convicted of murder, judge or jury has no information about the reality of innocent or guilty people. A reasonable sentence must be the consequence of applying appropriate methods on all the evidence, the proof of which is local information, and the reality of innocent or guilty people is global information.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: John Connor asked T-800, "Can you learn things you weren't programmed with? So you could be... you know, more human? And not be such a rogue all the time?" Even if this is just a movie scenario, we all want to know the answer to this question. And for researchers, the most interesting part is how to answer this question. In this essay, machine learning theories focus on solving various optimization problems so that we can model hypotheses of our observation. While the discussion of learning should focus on the behavior of the model, starting from a point that examines the relationships between observable appearance (local information), reality (global information), its representation, and the generalization of our intuitive understanding of learning, we have a necessary condition S that can be used to get the answer to John's question.
